channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Crowds Watch Israeli Airstrikes from a Beirut Hillside
item.description: Every night, dozens gather at the hillside to watch airstrikes rain down on the city’s southern suburbs. The ritual offers a window into the war — and proof that the once unimaginable is really happening.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watching an airstrike on the cluster of Lebanese neighborhoods known as Dahiya. Crowds of civilians and news reporters gather on a hillside with phones and cameras to observe from a distance.

item.title: Netanyahu Nearing Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire Decision, Officials Say
item.description: The United States is pushing Israel to reach a deal with the Lebanese militia by Thanksgiving, even as key details remained unresolved, Israeli officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke billowing after Israeli airstrikes in the Dahiya area south of Beirut on Monday.

item.title: DHL Cargo Plane Crashes Near Airport in Lithuania, Killing 1
item.description: The crash near Vilnius Airport sparked a fire in a residential area, officials said. One person on board was killed and three others were hospitalized.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Rescuers at the site where a DHL cargo plane crashed near Vilnius Airport in Lithuania on Monday.

item.title: Surge of Gang Violence in Haiti Leads U.N. Workers to Flee
item.description: A surge in gang violence over the past two weeks has led international aid organizations to rethink their staff levels in Haiti.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and David C. Adams
item.media:description: A clinic in Port-au-Prince run by Doctors Without Borders was closed after the organization announced that it was suspending operations in the capital.

item.title: UAE Arrests 3 in Connection With Murder of Israeli Rabbi
item.description: Israeli authorities say the abduction and killing of Rabbi Zvi Kogan was an act of antisemitic terrorism, but investigators have not yet stated a motive.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.media:description: A kosher supermarket in Dubai managed by Rabbi Zvi Kogan, who was kidnapped and murdered. Three Uzbeks have been charged with his death.

item.title: Protesters Defy Pakistan Crackdown to Demand Imran Khan’s Release
item.description: Protesters march to Pakistan’s capital amid a city lockdown and violent clashes with the police as political tensions surge.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Supporters of jailed former prime minister Imran Khan marched toward the Pakistani capital of Islamabad on Monday, after moving aside shipping containers placed by authorities to block them.

item.title: Hard-Right Candidate Wins First Round of Romania’s Presidential Election
item.description: Calin Georgescu, who had been widely dismissed as a fringe candidate, won the most votes on Sunday with 22.9 percent. He will face a more centrist opponent in the second round on Dec. 8.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Calin Georgescu, a dark-horse candidate without a party, has denounced Ukraine, NATO and the European Union.

item.title: Philippines President Slams Vice President’s Assassination Plot
item.description: Political turmoil has escalated after Vice President Sara Duterte claimed to have arranged for President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr.’s assassination if she is slain.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Aie Balagtas See
item.media:description: President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. of the Philippines with Vice President Sara Duterte in 2022, after their election victory. The alliance of their powerful political dynasties was supposed to be formidable, but it hasn’t lasted long.

item.title: U.K. Man Fighting for Ukraine Is Said to Be Captured in Russia
item.description: Russian state media reported that a British volunteer for the Ukrainian Army was captured amid fighting in the Kursk region.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military vehicle passing into Russia in August, when the surprise assault in the Kursk region began.

item.title: Spain Flooding: Why Did It Take So Long to Warn Residents?
item.description: Torrential rains in Valencia, in eastern Spain, caused flooding that killed more than 200 people. The deluge started inland. It took the authorities hours to warn those downstream.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Emergency workers searching for bodies on the outskirts of Valencia, in eastern Spain, this month after the deadly floods.

item.title: Palestinians See Echoes of Israel’s Gaza War in West Bank Raids
item.description: West Bank residents say Israeli forces are adopting tactics similar to the ones they are deploying in Gaza, including airstrikes and the use of Palestinians as human shields.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Azmat Khan and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:description: A damaged road at the entrance to the Nur Shams camp in the West Bank.

item.title: Rabbi Found Dead in Dubai in What Israel Calls Terrorist Act
item.description: The Israeli authorities called the killing of Rabbi Zvi Kogan an act of terrorism. The Emirati government said it had arrested three people in connection with the murder.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Ismaeel Naar
item.media:credit: Katarina Premfors for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabbi Zvi Kogan worked in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, as part of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement.

item.title: What Two Acclaimed Female-Directed Movies Say About Indian Cinema
item.description: “Laapataa Ladies” and “All We Imagine as Light” have both captivated audiences at home. But only one was able to get India’s nod for the best foreign film Oscar.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Pragati K.B.
item.media:description: Payal Kapadia, right, director of “All We Imagine as Light,” at the Cannes Film Festival in May, where her movie won the Grand Prix.

item.title: The Problem of Sorcery in Papua New Guinea
item.description: Tragedies in Papua New Guinea are often followed by accusations of sorcery and unspeakable acts of violence. That cycle has become more brutal in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Andrew Kutan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Korai, who was accused of killing a baby girl with black magic, at a shelter in Port Moresby, the capital of Papua New Guinea.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Trump’s Criminal Cases Likely to Be Dismissed
item.description: Plus, a possible cease-fire deal in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Jack Smith, the U.S. prosecutor who investigated and charged Donald Trump.

item.title: An A.I. Granny Is Phone Scammers’ Worst Nightmare
item.description: Daisy Harris, an A.I.-generated English granny, has been stymying scammers with meandering, time-wasting conversations. But can she actually make a dent in the flood of fraud?
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Michael McNerney/SOPA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: An O2 store in Lisburn, Northern Ireland. The company is taking a different approach to disrupting the operations of scammers who prey on its customers.

item.title: Storm Bert Batters UK With Rain and Fierce Winds, Killing at Least 3
item.description: Torrential rain doused most of the country, stymying travel and leading to widespread flooding, landslides, fallen trees and power outages.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A mud-covered street after flooding from Storm Bert in Cwmtillery, Wales, on Monday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Reaching a climate deal.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The entrance to the U.N. climate summit known as COP29, in Baku, Azerbaijan. The talks went deep into overtime.

item.title: Uruguay’s Center Left Reclaims Power in Presidential Election
item.description: After a campaign notable for the amiable tone from both sides, Yamandú Orsi was named the winner.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Álvaro Delgado, the candidate of the incumbent National Party, conceded defeat in Uruguay’s presidential election on Sunday.

item.title: Israel Conducts Widespread Strikes Near Beirut
item.description: As negotiators inch toward a cease-fire deal, the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon has intensified.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Smoke billowing over Beirut’s southern suburbs after an Israeli strike on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: U.N. Climate Talks End With a Deal
item.description: Plus, photographing the world’s food.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: A demonstration at the summit in Baku on Saturday.

item.title: World Seeks an End to Plastic Pollution at Talks in South Korea
item.description: Many nations hope to reduce the half a billion tons of plastic made each year. But pushback from plastic and oil producers, and Donald Trump’s election, could scuttle an agreement.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Volunteers collecting plastic waste in Manila last year. Nations around the world produce nearly half a billion tons of plastic each year, more than double the amount from two decades ago.

item.title: Hezbollah Fires Waves of Projectiles Into Israel After Deadly Strike in Lebanon
item.description: The waves of attacks on Sunday came amid diplomatic efforts to reach a cease-fire in the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Residents in Petah Tikva near Tel Aviv check the damage after rockets were fired from Lebanon on Sunday.

item.title: Egypt Feuds With Travel Blogger, Issuing 1,100-Word Response to Complaints
item.description: When a blogger criticized Cairo’s airport, Egypt’s government fired back, citing security footage, threatening legal action and asking, “Is it reasonable for a passenger to visit two lounges before a single flight?”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Rania Khaled
item.media:description: Cairo International Airport in 2022. Egypt’s Civil Aviation Ministry said it had “nearly” four stars from an independent evaluator.

item.title: The Amsterdam Attacks and the Long Shadow of ‘Pogroms’
item.description: Many have used an old word to refer to recent events. Is it accurate?
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Demonstrators holding a Palestinian flag in Amsterdam on Nov. 7.

item.title: The Lyrics to “+57” Causes Backlash in Colombia, a Reggaeton Hot Spot
item.description: A recent song’s explicit lyrics have prompted criticism that the music promotes harmful stereotypes about Colombia.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Medellín, Colombia’s second-largest city, has emerged as an epicenter of reggaeton, a genre with dance hall and hip-hop elements that was born in Panama and popularized by Puerto Rican artists.

item.title: Brazil Cracked Down on Corruption. Now It’s Undoing the Case.
item.description: Operation Car Wash, which started in Brazil, revealed a bribery scheme that spanned at least 12 countries. Brazil’s Supreme Court has reversed much of its impact.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas station and carwash in Brasília, Brazil’s capital, where a money-laundering operation prompted a vast corruption investigation that stretched throughout Latin America.

item.title: COP29 Climate Talks Get a Deal on Money, but Only After a Fight
item.description: The financing plan, which calls for $300 billion per year in support for developing nations, was immediately assailed as inadequate by a string of delegates.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A demonstration at the summit on Saturday. Experts have estimated the additional financing needs of developing countries at $1.3 trillion per year.

item.title: 2-Year-Old Gorilla Dies After Being Struck by Hydraulic Door at Zoo
item.description: A Calgary Zoo staff member mistakenly activated a door that struck the western lowland gorilla named Eyare, a report found.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:description: The entrance to the Calgary Zoo in Calgary, Canada, in 2023. A 2-year-old gorilla died after being struck by a hydraulic door at the zoo on Nov. 12.

item.title: Madeleine Riffaud, ‘the Girl Who Saved Paris,’ Dies at 100
item.description: Humiliated by a Nazi officer as a teenager, she joined the French Resistance. By the time she was 20, she had killed a German soldier, survived torture and captured a supply train.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: What’s Behind Ukraine and Russia’s Missile Brinkmanship?
item.description: Tit-for-tat moves this week included the use of American-made ballistic missiles to strike inside Russia, and new nuclear threats from Moscow. Neither appear to have influenced the war on the ground.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a frontline position near Toretsk, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: In South Africa, Food Poisoning Kills at Least 23 Children
item.description: The South African government said that nearly 900 people, many children, had fallen sick since September.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: United States National Library of Medicine
item.media:description: Six children died in Johannesburg’s Soweto township from food poisoning last month.

item.title: Sectarian Violence Kills at Least 25 in Northwest Pakistan
item.description: The clashes overnight between Sunni and Shiite tribes in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province came a day after gunmen ambushed a convoy of vehicles in the area.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: A mass burial on Friday for people killed a day earlier in an ambush in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province, Pakistan.

item.title: Your Heart’s Desire
item.description: Understanding what’s “for you” or “not for you” is part of refining taste. But what if it’s also closing you off to pleasure and connection?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Alberta Breaks With the Canadian Pension Model
item.description: The provincial government abruptly purged the board and senior leaders of Alberta’s pension fund, defying a long-held principle that funds should be free of political interference.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Stephen Harper, the former prime minister, is volunteering as the chairman of Alberta’s pension fund.

item.title: Kayaker Trapped on Australian River Has Leg Amputated in 20-Hour Rescue
item.description: The police in the state of Tasmania said all other efforts to help the man, a foreign tourist in his 60s, failed before the decision was made to amputate.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: With Memes and in State Media, Many Russians Cheer on Putin’s Threats
item.description: While support for Vladimir V. Putin’s threats resounded in pro-war venues, some Russians reacted with worry, gallows humor and apathy to the suggestions of striking the West and using nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin during a televised address to the nation on Thursday, saying that the country’s forces had hit Ukraine with a new midrange ballistic missile.

item.title: How a Nigerian Nurse Abducted by Boko Haram Planned Her Escape
item.description: After being abducted by an offshoot of Boko Haram in Nigeria six years ago, a Christian nurse describes her daring escape and how faith kept her alive.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Ruth Maclean
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alice Loksha Ngaddah was working as a nurse in a remote town she was kidnapped by terrorists in 2018.

item.title: Hezbollah Said to Be Using Copy of Israeli Missile Against Israel
item.description: The Lebanese militant group captured an advanced Israeli anti-tank missile in the 2006 war, and its ally, Iran, reverse-engineered it, Israeli officials say.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah members in Bint Jbeil, Lebanon, in July. The group is firing the rebranded Israeli missiles at Israeli military bases, communication systems and air-defense launchers, Israeli officials say.

item.title: Israel Strike Against Hezbollah in Lebanon Kills at Least 20
item.description: Israel was targeting a senior Hezbollah commander, but failed to kill him, one Israeli official said. Hezbollah officials said none of the group’s leaders were at the attack site.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Liam Stack and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: The site of an Israeli strike in Beirut’s Basta neighborhood on Saturday.

item.title: 55 Days Into Hunger Strike, Activist’s Mother Says She ‘Won’t Back Down’
item.description: Laila Soueif, the British-born mother of the Egyptian political prisoner Alaa Abd El Fattah, is demanding the U.K. do more to secure his release.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Laila Soueif, the mother of the Egyptian political prisoner Alaa Abd El Fattah in 2022. She stopped eating on Sept. 29, after it became clear that her son would not be released after serving a five-year sentence.

item.title: Formula for Power in Modi’s India: Cash, Detentions and Luxe Resorts
item.description: With a tactic known as “resort politics,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party has been accused of using brute force to take over Indian state governments.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Nitin Deshmukh, a lawmaker in the state of Maharashtra, India, said he was detained, including at a government hospital, and pressured to join rebel politicians in an uprising.

item.title: A Lesson for America? Reversing Populist Policies Is Tough, Poland Finds.
item.description: The country’s new leaders are trying to undo changes, like abortion restrictions and politicized courts, made by their hard-right predecessors. It “takes longer than you expect,” one minister said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Anna Liminowicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court in Warsaw. The previous government, under the Law and Justice party, stacked Polish courts with right-wing loyalists.

item.title: How Can the I.C.C. Prosecute Leaders of Israel, Which Is Not a Member?
item.description: The jurisdiction of the court in The Hague can extend beyond member states.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson and Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laurens Van Putten/Anp, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague in the Netherlands.

item.title: Iran Declares It Is Doing More Nuclear Enrichment After I.A.E.A. Rebuke
item.description: With thousands of advanced centrifuges on standby, Tehran says it is now spinning more, which could increase its stockpile of near-bomb-grade atomic fuel.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: A satellite view of Iran’s Fordo fuel enrichment plant inside a mountain northeast of the city of Qum.

item.title: Conor McGregor, U.F.C. Fighter, Is Held Liable for Sexual Assault in Ireland
item.description: The mixed martial arts fighter known as “Notorious” was ordered to pay the equivalent of about $260,000 to a woman who said he raped her in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The mixed martial arts fighter Conor McGregor outside the High Court in Dublin on Friday.

item.title: Bolsonaro’s Right Wing Movement Faces Backlash After Coup Accusations
item.description: Accusations that former far-right President Jair Bolsonaro plotted a coup arose after a former top aide of his was implicated in a plan to kill the current president.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Brazilian police are seeking charges against Jair Bolsonaro, the former far-right president, accusing him of taking part in a coup plot.

item.title: Pat King Found Guilty for Role in ‘Freedom Convoy’
item.description: The verdict was in the high-profile case of Pat King, a man accused of helping provoke disruptions during the so-called trucker convoy, which paralyzed Canada’s capital during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pat King, a prominent figure in Canada’s protests against Covid restrictions in 2022, surrounded by supporters on Friday while leaving court in Ottawa, Ontario.

item.title: South Africa’s A.N.C. Rejects Jacob Zuma’s Appeal Against His Expulsion
item.description: The country’s governing party had severed ties with the former president in July after he campaigned for an opposition party in the last general election.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Former South African President Jacob Zuma in court in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, in August.

item.title: Terms of Proposed Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire Begin to Take Shape, Officials Say
item.description: Key details still needed to be worked out between Israel and Hezbollah, and disagreements could scuttle or delay any deal, the officials said. But some cited reasons for cautious optimism.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Isabel Kershner and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli strike in Mar Elias, central Beirut, Lebanon, on November 18.

item.title: At COP29 Politicians Are Talking About Climate Change. Here’s What’s Happening.
item.description: Every month so far has seen floods, fires, smashed heat records or some combination of extreme weather. Little time remains for leaders to agree on what to do about it.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: R. Satish Babu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Fires and punishing heat in a suburb of Chennai, India, in May.

item.title: Orban Invites Netanyahu to Hungary, Flouting I.C.C. Arrest Warrant
item.description: Hungary, unlike the United States, is a signatory to the court, which accused the Israeli leader of war crimes in Gaza. Responses to the warrant from other European countries were varied.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with his Hungarian counterpart, Viktor Orban, in Budapest in 2017.

item.title: Guard at U.S. Embassy in Norway Accused of Spying for Russia and Iran
item.description: The Norwegian man was arrested this week in Oslo and ordered jailed pending further investigation in what the authorities called a ‘very serious case.’
item.dc:creator: Henrik Pryser Libell and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oslo at sunset. Authorities in Norway have arrested a man who worked as a security guard at the United States embassy there.

item.title: Merkel Memoir Recalls What It Was Like Dealing With Trump and Putin
item.description: The new book by former Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany also aims to justify decisions she made that are still affecting her country and the rest of Europe.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: An awkward silence between Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Donald J. Trump in the Oval Office in 2017, shortly after his inauguration.

item.title: Russia Supplies Antiaircraft Missiles, to North Korea, the South Says
item.description: Pyongyang has long coveted an advanced air-defense system to guard against missiles and war planes from the United States and South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un of North Korea with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in a broadcast shown in Seoul this month.

item.title: Israel Strikes Across Lebanon After Ordering Evacuations of Southern Towns
item.description: The wide-scale bombardment continued a day after a U.S. envoy held talks with Israeli officials on a possible cease-fire with Hezbollah militants.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Liam Stack
